Award.AwardTitle: Molecular Simulation Study of Interfacial Phenomena Related to Geological CO2 Storage

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The capacity of geological storage of CO2 can be estimated by understanding how one of the key mechanisms for gas leakage, capillary breakthrough, behaves under sequestration conditions. The threshold pressure at which this occurs is directly related to the interfacial tension( between brine and carbon dioxide) and the contact angle of a brine droplet at a mineral surface. Since the conditions for CO2 sequestration are not easily accessible by experiments, this proposal aims to develop a series of tools to facilitate the study of brine-CO2-mineral systems via molecular simulation. This type of information can be used to get a good understanding of the breakthrough pressure for CO2 release from the rock surface and can also be used to develop molecular-level strategies for altering interfacial properties (e.g. surfactant treatments).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The average temperature of the earth’s atmosphere and oceans has risen steadily since the late 19th century. The changes in the earth’s climate induced by increased concentration levels of greenhouse gases within the atmosphere have potentially profound implications for current and future generations.  Possible ramifications include decreased crop yields, a further retreat of the glaciers, and more frequent droughts and heavy rainfalls.  In an effort to address concerns related to global warming, scientists and engineers have placed an increased emphasis on the development of strategies for the capture and storage of greenhouse gases.

Geological sequestration represents a promising means to store carbon dioxide for relatively long periods of time (several hundred to several thousands of years).  Possible storage locations include deep saline aquifers, oil reservoirs, and unmineable coal seams.  Saline aquifers have seen limited use only. While many promising saline aquifers exist for carbon dioxide sequestration, safety concerns regarding the potential for gas leakage from reservoirs have slowed the implementation of strategies that utilize aquifers.  Many of these concerns persist due to outstanding questions regarding the behaviors of systems consisting of brine (salt water), oil, carbon dioxide, and rock (e.g. sandstone, limestone).

The geological storage process involves the injection of high pressure carbon dioxide into an environment consisting of brine and oil. The carbon dioxide is retained by a mineral caprock that resides above the reservoir. Caprocks are porous materials that are typically composed of carbonate and/or silicate minerals.  In practice, it is desirable to deliver the maximum amount of gas that a reservoir can handle safely. This threshold is reached when the reservoir pressure meets a “breakthrough pressure”. It is at this point that carbon dioxide begins to leak through the caprock structure.

The breakthrough pressure is defined by two key properties: (1) the contact angle of a droplet of brine that sits on a mineral surface in a carbon dioxide rich environment (see Figure 1) and (2) the interfacial tension between the brine and carbon dioxide rich phases. The interfacial tension provides a measure of the adhesive forces between the brine and carbon dioxide phases. It follows that one must understand well how these properties evolve with reservoir conditions when designing geological storage solutions. Experimental approaches for characterizing these properties tend to be difficult and expensive. Our aim was to develop computer simulation tools for estimating properties of interest over a wide range of conditions.

The goal of this project was to develop and implement molecular simulation strategies for probing outstanding questions related to geological sequestration of greenhouse gases. Specific objectives included: (1) develop of a series of tools that facilitate the study of mineral-brine-carbon dioxide systems via molecular simulation, (2) obtain a better understanding of the factors that control wettability in mineral-brine-carbon dioxide systems, and (3) extend the applicability of the computational tools to closely related systems of practical relevance.

We developed a technique that enables one to determine the pressure dependence of the two key properties noted above. Information of this type is useful for the design of sequestration strategies. Figure 2 provides a snapshot from a molecular simulation. We focused on a computational strategy that involves calculation and subsequent analysis of an interface potential (see Figure 3). Such an approach provides a number of advantages in terms of the quality and quantity of information that one can extract from molecular simulations.

We next performed a series of benchmarking calculations with a system consisting of water, carbon dioxide, and silica. Molecular simulation methods take as input a molecular model, which provides a description of how molecules interact with one another. Several molecular models have been developed for water, carbon dioxide, and silica, and we wanted to gain insight regarding the sensitivity of the results to the molecular model selected.

We then employed the methods we developed to determine the properties of select model systems over a wide range of temperature and pressure. Figure 4 provides an illustrative example of the output, with the top plot showing the interfacial tension and the bottom plot providing the contact angle. The estimates were generated at a temperature of 323 K and cover a range of pressures relevant to saline aquifers. When possible, we carefully compared simulation estimates with experimental data.

The simulation approach was also used to explore the influence of surface hydrophilicity (water preference) on the properties of interest. In practice this surface characteristic evolves with reservoir conditions, such as the pH and salt concentration.

As the project unfolded, we recognized an opportunity to extend our modeling strategy to closely related mineral-brine-oil systems. These systems are of significant importance to the oil and gas industry. This extension proved to be successful, and demonstrated the flexibility of the methods we developed.
